ygData.msgSnippet: msi files are used by the Windows Installer, which is the standard way to install software on Windows 2000 and Windows XP.  The capability to use these files

'msi' files are used by the Windows Installer, which is the standard 
way to install software on Windows 2000 and Windows XP.  The capability 
to use these files is built-in to the operating system. If the 
operating system doesn't recognize it, you are probably using an older 
version of Windows,  If so, you can download the Windows Installer from 
the Microsoft website, which may fix the problem.  However, I compile 
the Cantera Windows binary version on a Win 2000 machine, and don't 
know if it runs on older OS versions.

As far as building from the source, make sure you have the source 
distributioo (not the binary distribution), and have a file called 
'configure' in the Cantera top-level directory.  You may need to type 
'./configure' at the bash prompt instead of 'configure', depending on 
how your PATH environment variable is set.

Hope this helps.

Dave Goodwin
